mainmatter.p: In type theory, natural number is defined using peano encoding. The type \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N is formed by the formation rule: \frac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \mathbb {N} \text {-form} ⊢N typeN-form \frac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \mathbb {N} \text {-form} ⊢N type​N-form

Peano's first axiom postulates the existence of a natural number 0000. The introduction rule for \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N has a 0000 constructor and a successor function. \frac {}{ \vdash0 : \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-0} \quad \frac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-succ} ⊢0:NN-intro-0⊢succ:N→NN-intro-succ \frac {}{ \vdash0 : \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-0} \quad \frac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-succ} ⊢0:N​N-intro-0⊢succ:N→N​N-intro-succ

The elimination rule is actually the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N: In order to show that \forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)∀n:N.P(n)\forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)∀n:N.P(n) holds, it suffices to show that P(0)P(0)P(0)P(0) holds and that \forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n))∀n:N.P(n)→P(succ(n))\forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n))∀n:N.P(n)→P(succ(n)) holds. The type theoretical induction principle is therefore formulated using a type family PPPP over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N: \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &, \, n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S): \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ, n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢p0:P(0)Γ⊢pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n))Γ⊢indN(p0,pS):Π(n:N)P(n)(N-ind) \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &, \, n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S): \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ⊢indN​(p0​,pS​):Π(n:N)​P(n)ΓΓΓ​,n:N⊢P(n) type⊢p0​:P(0)⊢pS​:Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​​(N-ind) The induction principle tells us what we need to do in order to construct a dependent function \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN\text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN​ of type \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n)Π(n:N)P(n)\Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n)Π(n:N)​P(n). We might alternatively write the induction principle as: \frac { \Gamma ,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} : \left (P(0) \to \left ( \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \right ) \to \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \right ) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ,n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢indN:(P(0)→(Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n)))→Π(n:N)P(n))(N-ind) \frac { \Gamma ,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} : \left (P(0) \to \left ( \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \right ) \to \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \right ) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ⊢indN​:(P(0)→(Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n)))→Π(n:N)​P(n))Γ,n:N⊢P(n) type​(N-ind)

The computation rule asserts that the dependent function \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN\text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN​ behaves as expected: \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,m) \equiv \begin {cases} p_0& \text {if }m=0 \\ p_S(n, \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,n))& \text {if }m= \text {succ} (n) \end {cases} }( \mathbb {N} \text {-comp}) Γ,n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢p0:P(0)Γ⊢pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n))indN(p0,pS,m)≡{p0if m=0pS(n,indN(p0,pS,n))if m=succ(n)(N-comp) \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,m) \equiv \begin {cases} p_0& \text {if }m=0 \\ p_S(n, \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,n))& \text {if }m= \text {succ} (n) \end {cases} }( \mathbb {N} \text {-comp}) indN​(p0​,pS​,m)≡{p0​pS​(n,indN​(p0​,pS​,n))​if m=0if m=succ(n)​ΓΓΓ​,n:N⊢P(n) type⊢p0​:P(0)⊢pS​:Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​​(N-comp)

frontmatter.title: Natural Numbers \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N

mainmatter.p: In previous post, we have seen the basic inference rules of type theory. Now we will see the definition of natural numbers as an inductive type. Refer to HoTT Book and Egbert Rijke's.
In classical mathematics, the Peano axioms are a set of axioms for the natural numbers, an important object in mathematics.
In type theory, the type \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N of natural number is an inductive type. Just like in dependent function type, we need four inference rules to define the natural numbers.

In type theory, natural number is defined using peano encoding. The type \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N is formed by the formation rule: \frac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \mathbb {N} \text {-form} ⊢N typeN-form \frac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \mathbb {N} \text {-form} ⊢N type​N-form

Peano's first axiom postulates the existence of a natural number 0000. The introduction rule for \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N has a 0000 constructor and a successor function. \frac {}{ \vdash0 : \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-0} \quad \frac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-succ} ⊢0:NN-intro-0⊢succ:N→NN-intro-succ \frac {}{ \vdash0 : \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-0} \quad \frac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } \mathbb {N} \text {-intro-succ} ⊢0:N​N-intro-0⊢succ:N→N​N-intro-succ

The elimination rule is actually the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N: In order to show that \forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)∀n:N.P(n)\forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)∀n:N.P(n) holds, it suffices to show that P(0)P(0)P(0)P(0) holds and that \forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n))∀n:N.P(n)→P(succ(n))\forall n: \mathbb {N} .P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n))∀n:N.P(n)→P(succ(n)) holds. The type theoretical induction principle is therefore formulated using a type family PPPP over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N: \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &, \, n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S): \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ, n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢p0:P(0)Γ⊢pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n))Γ⊢indN(p0,pS):Π(n:N)P(n)(N-ind) \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &, \, n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S): \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ⊢indN​(p0​,pS​):Π(n:N)​P(n)ΓΓΓ​,n:N⊢P(n) type⊢p0​:P(0)⊢pS​:Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​​(N-ind) The induction principle tells us what we need to do in order to construct a dependent function \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN\text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN​ of type \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n)Π(n:N)P(n)\Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n)Π(n:N)​P(n). We might alternatively write the induction principle as: \frac { \Gamma ,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} : \left (P(0) \to \left ( \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \right ) \to \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \right ) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ,n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢indN:(P(0)→(Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n)))→Π(n:N)P(n))(N-ind) \frac { \Gamma ,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} }{ \Gamma \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} : \left (P(0) \to \left ( \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \right ) \to \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \right ) }( \mathbb {N} \text {-ind}) Γ⊢indN​:(P(0)→(Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n)))→Π(n:N)​P(n))Γ,n:N⊢P(n) type​(N-ind)

The computation rule asserts that the dependent function \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN\text {ind}_ \mathbb {N}indN​ behaves as expected: \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,m) \equiv \begin {cases} p_0& \text {if }m=0 \\ p_S(n, \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,n))& \text {if }m= \text {succ} (n) \end {cases} }( \mathbb {N} \text {-comp}) Γ,n:N⊢P(n) typeΓ⊢p0:P(0)Γ⊢pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n))indN(p0,pS,m)≡{p0if m=0pS(n,indN(p0,pS,n))if m=succ(n)(N-comp) \frac { \begin {align*} \Gamma &,n: \mathbb {N} \vdash P(n) \space \text {type} \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_0:P(0) \\ \Gamma & \vdash p_S: \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} }{ \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,m) \equiv \begin {cases} p_0& \text {if }m=0 \\ p_S(n, \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} (p_0,p_S,n))& \text {if }m= \text {succ} (n) \end {cases} }( \mathbb {N} \text {-comp}) indN​(p0​,pS​,m)≡{p0​pS​(n,indN​(p0​,pS​,n))​if m=0if m=succ(n)​ΓΓΓ​,n:N⊢P(n) type⊢p0​:P(0)⊢pS​:Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​​(N-comp)
Now let's use the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N to perform some basic construction over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N.

frontmatter.title: Addition over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N

mainmatter.p: We define addition over \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N using the type theoretical induction principle of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N. \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) addN:N→(N→N) \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) addN​:N→(N→N) which satisfies the following specification: \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (n, 0)&: \equiv n \\ \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))&: \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN(n,0):≡naddN(m,succ(n)):≡succ(addN(m,n)) \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (n, 0)&: \equiv n \\ \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))&: \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN​(n,0)addN​(m,succ(n))​:≡n:≡succ(addN​(m,n))​ abbreviated as m + nm+nm + nm+n for \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)addN(m,n)\text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)addN​(m,n).

tree.mainmatter: We construct the additon by perform induction over the second variable nnnn. That is, to construct an element m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} m:N⊢addN(m):N→N m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} m:N⊢addN​(m):N→N The context \Gamma \equiv m: \mathbb {N}Γ≡m:N\Gamma \equiv m: \mathbb {N}Γ≡m:N is fixed. Therefore we need to construct: \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} \end {align*} Γ⊢add-zeroN(m):NΓ⊢add-succN(m):N→N \begin {align*} \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \\ \Gamma & \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} \end {align*} ΓΓ​⊢add-zeroN​(m):N⊢add-succN​(m):N→N​ The \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N}add-zeroN\text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N}add-zeroN​ is defined to be identity function trivially. To see how \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN\text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN​ is defined, we need to perform induction: \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))& \equiv \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {succ} (n)) \\ & \equiv \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n, \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \\ & \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN(m,succ(n))≡indN(add-zeroN(m),add-succN(m),succ(n))≡add-succN(m,n,addN(m,n))≡succ(addN(m,n)) \begin {align*} \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m, \text {succ} (n))& \equiv \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {succ} (n)) \\ & \equiv \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n, \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \\ & \equiv \text {succ} ( \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n)) \end {align*} addN​(m,succ(n))​≡indN​(add-zeroN​(m),add-succN​(m),succ(n))≡add-succN​(m,n,addN​(m,n))≡succ(addN​(m,n))​ Hence \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN\text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN​ is defined as: \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n,x) \equiv \text {succ} (x) add-succN(m,n,x)≡succ(x) \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m,n,x) \equiv \text {succ} (x) add-succN​(m,n,x)≡succ(x) A formal construction of \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN\text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N}add-succN​ is as follows: \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \quad \dfrac { \dfrac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \quad \dfrac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ n: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} , n: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \lambda n. \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \equiv \lambda m. \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) } \text {Block-1} ⊢N type⊢N type⊢succ:N→Nn:N⊢succ:N→Nm:N,n:N⊢succ:N→Nm:N⊢λn.succ:N→(N→N)m:N⊢add-succN(m):≡λm.succ:N→(N→N)Block-1 \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \quad \dfrac { \dfrac {}{ \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} } \quad \dfrac {}{ \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ n: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} , n: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \lambda n. \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \equiv \lambda m. \text {succ} : \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) } \text {Block-1} m:N⊢add-succN​(m):≡λm.succ:N→(N→N)m:N⊢λn.succ:N→(N→N)m:N,n:N⊢succ:N→N⊢N type​n:N⊢succ:N→N⊢N type​⊢succ:N→N​​​​​Block-1 Finally we combine the derivation together: \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash m: \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \equiv m: \mathbb {N} } \quad \dfrac { \text {Block-1}}{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m)): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \equiv \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m)): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } ⊢N typem:N⊢m:Nm:N⊢add-zeroN(m):≡m:NBlock-1m:N⊢add-succN(m):N→(N→N)m:N⊢indN(add-zeroN(m),add-succN(m)):N→Nm:N⊢addN(m):≡indN(add-zeroN(m),add-succN(m)):N→N \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \dfrac { \vdash \mathbb {N} \space \text {type} }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash m: \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \equiv m: \mathbb {N} } \quad \dfrac { \text {Block-1}}{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} ) } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m)): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } }{ m: \mathbb {N} \vdash \text {add}_ \mathbb {N} (m): \equiv \text {ind}_ \mathbb {N} ( \text {add-zero}_ \mathbb {N} (m), \text {add-succ}_ \mathbb {N} (m)): \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } m:N⊢addN​(m):≡indN​(add-zeroN​(m),add-succN​(m)):N→Nm:N⊢indN​(add-zeroN​(m),add-succN​(m)):N→Nm:N⊢add-zeroN​(m):≡m:Nm:N⊢m:N⊢N type​​m:N⊢add-succN​(m):N→(N→N)Block-1​​​

mainmatter.p: Recall the definition of addition function \text {add}: \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} )add:N→(N→N)\text {add}: \mathbb {N} \to ( \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} )add:N→(N→N) satisfying the specification: \begin {align*} m + 0 & : \equiv m \\ m + \text {succ} (n) & : \equiv \text {succ} (m + n) \end {align*} m+0:≡mm+succ(n):≡succ(m+n) \begin {align*} m + 0 & : \equiv m \\ m + \text {succ} (n) & : \equiv \text {succ} (m + n) \end {align*} m+0m+succ(n)​:≡m:≡succ(m+n)​ Such definition is enough to characterize the addition function. Because it postulates te behavior of \text {add}_ \mathbb {N}addN\text {add}_ \mathbb {N}addN​ at the constructor of \mathbb {N}N\mathbb {N}N

More generally, we can define a dependent function f: \Pi n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)f:Πn:N.P(n)f: \Pi n: \mathbb {N} .P(n)f:Πn:N.P(n) by induction on nnnn using \begin {align*} p_0 & : P(0) \\ p_S & : \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} p0:P(0)pS:Π(n:N)P(n)→P(succ(n)) \begin {align*} p_0 & : P(0) \\ p_S & : \Pi _{(n: \mathbb {N} )}P(n) \to P( \text {succ} (n)) \end {align*} p0​pS​​:P(0):Π(n:N)​P(n)→P(succ(n))​ Just present the definition by writing \begin {align*} f(0) & : \equiv p_0 \\ f( \text {succ} (n)) & : \equiv p_S(n,f(n)) \end {align*} f(0):≡p0f(succ(n)):≡pS(n,f(n)) \begin {align*} f(0) & : \equiv p_0 \\ f( \text {succ} (n)) & : \equiv p_S(n,f(n)) \end {align*} f(0)f(succ(n))​:≡p0​:≡pS​(n,f(n))​ ffff is said to be defined by pattern matching on the variable nnnn.

The Fibonacci function is a well-known function in mathematics. It is defined by pattern matching on the variable nnnn as follows: \begin {align*} \text {fib}(0) & : \equiv 0 \\ \text {fib}(1) & : \equiv 1 \\ \text {fib}(n+2) & : \equiv \text {fib}(n) + \text {fib}(n+1) \end {align*} fib(0):≡0fib(1):≡1fib(n+2):≡fib(n)+fib(n+1) \begin {align*} \text {fib}(0) & : \equiv 0 \\ \text {fib}(1) & : \equiv 1 \\ \text {fib}(n+2) & : \equiv \text {fib}(n) + \text {fib}(n+1) \end {align*} fib(0)fib(1)fib(n+2)​:≡0:≡1:≡fib(n)+fib(n+1)​
